_description: Section guidance for Record Inspection. Keyed by sheet name, document_role::document_type, or document_role. Sheet-name keys provide category-specific analyst checklists.

what_to_look_for: Start by confirming the correct Account is linked (no test accounts, no legacy/duplicate accounts for the same artist or partner).
Check Contract Type / Deal Type (e.g., CMA, CPA, Distribution, Publishing) matches both the uploaded contract and the internal request/notes.
Validate Stage and Close Date are realistic: mark as Closed–Won only when the governing contract is fully executed, and set Close Date to align with the execution/effective date range.
Ensure key classifiers are set: deal subtype (catalog only vs frontline vs mixed), primary artist/roster, and territory/region flags (US only, WW, EU, etc.).

Confirm linkage to downstream records: at least one Financial record (if required for this deal type), Contract(s) attached, and any relevant V2 Addons visible (terminations, amendments, LE revisions).
Scan notes/description for anything that contradicts the structured fields (e.g., a different deal type, different party, or different commercial terms).
common_failure_modes: Wrong or missing Contract Type / Deal Type, causing mis-routing to the wrong workflow or downstream system.
Opportunity linked to the wrong Account (similar artist names, old imprint/label entities, holding companies instead of the contracting party).
Stage set to Closed–Won before the agreement is actually executed, or never updated after signing.
Close Date set to 'today' or the ingestion date instead of matching the real contract timeline.
Missing linkage to Financial or Contracts objects, so downstream tools cannot find the deal.
Notes or attachments describe a different deal than what is configured in the structured fields (e.g., catalog-only vs full rights).

what_to_look_for: Verify the legal name of the artist/client/partner matches the most recent governing contract (header and signature blocks).
Confirm Account Type / Role (artist, label, distributor, publisher, brand, internal entity) reflects how this party appears in contracts.
Check core identity fields: country / primary operating territory and any external or internal IDs used by other systems.
Ensure this Account is the canonical record for the entity: no obvious duplicates representing the same artist/partner.
Review linked Contacts to ensure primary contacts reflect current business reality (A&R, legal, finance, management).
common_failure_modes: Multiple Accounts for the same artist/partner with slightly different spellings, punctuation, or legacy naming.
Using an old label/parent entity name instead of the current contracting entity from the latest deal.
Country / territory on the Account that does not match the jurisdiction or primary territory in the contract.
Incorrect Account Type (e.g., marking an artist as a label, or a distributor as an internal entity).
Opportunities / Contracts created against secondary or legacy Accounts instead of the canonical one.
Contacts left as primary even though they are no longer relevant (old managers, ex-label reps, outdated email addresses).

what_to_look_for: Confirm financial terms match the governing contract(s): advances (amount, currency, recoupment), fees / rev-share or royalty percentages, minimum guarantees, caps, and floors.
Verify units and formats: percentages vs decimals (e.g., 30 vs 0.3), currency codes vs symbols (USD, GBP, EUR), and that numeric fields do not contain text.
Check term and payment structure: correct start/end dates for financial obligations and installment schedules that match the contract (upfront vs phased payments).
Ensure links to the correct Opportunity, Account, and Contract(s) so downstream reporting and payment systems can trace the source deal.
Confirm that any later amendments, restatements, or V2 Addons that change money terms are reflected here (updated rates, advances, caps, or fee structures).
common_failure_modes: Percentages entered as decimals (or vice versa), leading to 10x over- or under-payment issues.
Wrong currency selected (e.g., USD instead of EUR) or mixed-currency terms captured as if they were single-currency.
Typographical errors on amounts (extra zero, missing zero, decimal in the wrong place).
Financial terms not updated after an amendment or restatement that clearly changes rates, advances, or guarantees.
Financial record exists but is not linked to the corresponding Opportunity/Contract, breaking traceability.
Key financial values captured only in free-text notes or attachments instead of structured fields.

what_to_look_for: Confirm the Schedule is linked to the correct parent Contract / Agreement (matching party names, deal type, and dates).
Identify what the Schedule is defining: territories, term periods, services, obligations, options, or other non-catalog parameters.
Validate that effective dates and scope (territory, term, rights) align with the main agreement unless the Schedule explicitly states it is amending or overriding earlier terms.
Ensure fields describing rights and obligations are specific and machine-usable (e.g., 'WW excl. US' instead of 'global-ish' or informal language).
Check consistency with existing system vocabulary for territories, right types, service types, and platforms.
Verify whether this Schedule is the first in the chain, a replacement, or a supplement, and capture that in the appropriate field or status if available.
common_failure_modes: Schedule linked to the wrong contract (similar artist, similar deal name, or prior deal with the same partner).
Term or territory values that conflict with the main agreement but are not clearly flagged as overrides.
Overly vague descriptions that cannot be used in automation (e.g., 'standard rights', 'normal term', 'all usual platforms').
No indication of whether this Schedule supersedes an earlier schedule or simply adds to it, making it hard to interpret sequence.
Schedules that primarily list catalog/assets stored as generic schedules instead of catalog-specific schedules (and vice versa).

what_to_look_for: Verify each catalog row has the key identifiers required by downstream systems: title, artist, ISRC/UPC, and internal catalog ID where available.
Confirm the Schedule Catalog is attached to the correct parent Contract / Opportunity / Account and that the deal context (type, term, territory) matches expectations.
Check that assets and territories match the intended scope: full catalog, defined subset, or termination/transfer subset only.
Look for indicators of partial supersession: only some assets listed as terminated, transferred, or subject to changed terms.
Ensure there are no obvious duplicates or conflicts with existing catalog schedules for the same assets (e.g., two different owners or royalty rates).
If this schedule updates a prior schedule, confirm that the older schedule’s status or interpretation is clear (replaced vs co-existing).
common_failure_modes: Missing or inconsistent ISRC/UPC values, making it difficult to match assets to internal catalog records.
The same asset appearing in multiple schedules with different ownership/rights or different rates and no clear effective ordering.
Schedule labeled 'full catalog' but clearly missing major releases or obvious catalog items from other systems.
Catalog schedule not marked as new, updated, or termination schedule, making its relationship to prior schedules unclear.
Schedule used to represent a partial termination or partial release of catalog but not tagged as partial in the system, leading to over-termination or under-termination in automation.

what_to_look_for: Confirm contract type is correctly classified: main agreement, amendment, termination, side letter, schedule, catalog schedule, work-for-hire, restatement, or other applicable subtype.
Check party names and roles: they should match the Account and any related Opportunities, including correct legal entities and trade names.
Validate key dates: Effective Date, Signature/Execution Date, and (if applicable) Termination Date, and confirm they are consistent with Salesforce / HUB records and the intended deal timeline.
Confirm linkage: the Contract record is attached to the correct Account, Opportunity, Financial records, and relevant Schedules / Schedule Catalogs.
Identify whether this document replaces, modifies, or adds to previous documents, and whether the effect is full or partial (especially for terminations and catalog or territory changes).
Check that any consequential changes (splits, term, territory, catalog ownership) implied by this contract are reflected or planned in Financials, Schedules, and V2 Addons.
common_failure_modes: Mis-labeling documents (e.g., a side letter stored as an amendment, a termination stored as a standard amendment, or a restatement treated as a simple amendment).
Missing or incorrect Effective Date, causing timeline ordering issues or making it unclear which document governs when.
Contract uploaded or logged in the system but not connected to the relevant Account/Opportunity, breaking visibility for other teams.
A new restatement not marked as the 'current' main agreement, leaving old agreements apparently active in the system.
Partial terminations or partial rights changes treated as full terminations or full supersession in the system.
Signature blocks incomplete, inconsistent with the header, or obviously not fully executed while the record is flagged as final.

what_to_look_for: Confirm each Addon is tied to the correct base contract / opportunity and that the relationship type (e.g., amendment, termination flow, revision) is correct.
Identify the primary purpose of the Addon: termination management, partial supersession, LE revisions, contract drafting or approval workflow, or other specialized behavior.
Check that key Addon fields accurately reflect the real-world intent: termination type (full vs partial), effective dates, catalog or asset selection, and which clauses/sections are being changed.
Ensure status fields are accurate and up to date: Draft, Proposed, In Review, Executed, Offboarded, or equivalent lifecycle stages.
Validate that changes implied by the Addon are reflected downstream or queued for update: updated Financial terms, new or updated Schedules, catalog terminations or transfers, timeline adjustments.
Confirm there are no overlapping or conflicting Addons acting on the same assets/territories/periods without a clear precedence rule.
common_failure_modes: Addon object created but never fully wired: not linked to the right base contract or opportunity, or missing catalog/asset references.
Wrong termination type (partial vs full) captured vs what the termination schedule or document actually states.
Changes captured in an Addon (e.g., new rates, partial terminations) not propagated to Financial, Schedule, Catalog, or Timeline View.
Multiple Addons targeting the same assets or rights (e.g., two competing terminations) with no explicit ordering or conflict resolution.
Addon status left in 'Draft' or 'Proposed' even though the underlying contract has been executed (or terminated), leading to stale or misleading data.
Using an Addon as a generic note store instead of modeling specific, structured changes, making it hard for automation to act on it.

what_to_look_for: Verify the effective date and overall term structure (initial term plus any renewal/option language).
Confirm all party names and defined entities in the header match the signature blocks and the Account in the system.
Check for explicit references to prior agreements or amendments that this Master Service Agreement replaces or incorporates.
Validate territory and rights scope: which services, platforms, or rights are covered, and for which territories.
Verify payment terms and rates are either clearly specified here or properly referenced via attached schedules.
Look for auto-renewal or evergreen clauses and note any notice periods required to terminate or opt out.
Confirm termination conditions (for cause, for convenience, by mutual agreement) and any special wind-down obligations.
common_failure_modes: Mismatched party names between the header, recitals, and signature blocks (e.g., different entity names or missing subsidiaries).
Missing effective date or ambiguous term language, making it unclear when the agreement starts or ends.
Unsigned or partially executed agreement stored as if it were fully in effect.
Territory or scope language that conflicts with later amendments or schedules but is not clearly overridden.
Rate or fee schedules referenced in the MSA but not attached, incomplete, or mismatched to the system’s Financial configuration.

what_to_look_for: Verify the amendment clearly references the correct original agreement (title, date, and parties).
Check the effective date of the rate change and whether it applies retroactively or only going forward.
Validate old vs new rate values and confirm which revenue streams, products, or territories they apply to.
Confirm all affected catalog items, services, or deal segments are listed or clearly described in the amendment or its schedules.
Verify that authorized signatories for each party have signed and that the signature dates are reasonable relative to the effective date.
common_failure_modes: Amendment references the wrong original agreement number, date, or party combination.
Rate change effective date conflicts with the original term or with other amendments in the timeline.
Missing catalog items or revenue streams that clearly should be affected by the new rate but are not mentioned.
Ambiguous language about which territories, services, or platforms the new rates apply to.
Amendment signed by an unauthorized or clearly incorrect signatory compared to prior agreements.

what_to_look_for: Verify new territories are clearly defined (e.g., specific countries, regions, or 'WW excl. X' formulations).
Check whether the extension affects the existing rate structure or creates new rates for the extended territories.
Confirm the effective date of the extension and ensure it aligns with or properly extends the original term.
Validate that the extended territories do not conflict with existing territory grants in this or other agreements for the same catalog.
Review any carve-outs or exclusions that limit the extension (e.g., certain services or platforms not included).
common_failure_modes: Ambiguous territory definitions that do not map cleanly to standard territory lists.
Conflicts with existing territory grants in other deals for the same artist or catalog (double-grants).
Missing rate terms or unclear economic treatment for newly added territories.
Extension language that appears to contradict original exclusivity or prior third-party deals without clear resolution.

what_to_look_for: Verify all catalog items have valid identifiers: at minimum title and artist, and ideally ISRC/UPC and internal catalog IDs.
Check for duplicate entries within the schedule (same ISRC/UPC or internal ID listed more than once).
Validate that any rate/royalty or participation values are numeric and in the correct format (percentage vs decimal).
Confirm territory assignments per item (if applicable) match the overall agreement or any specified deviations.
Look for items with missing metadata that would prevent matching to internal catalog or platform data.
If this schedule updates or terminates prior schedules, confirm that the intended changes (adds, removals, terminations) are clear row by row.
common_failure_modes: Duplicate catalog item entries with different rates or conflicting ownership information.
Missing or invalid item identifiers (blank ISRC/UPC or obviously malformed values).
Non-numeric or free-text values in rate columns that cannot drive reporting or payment calculations.
Items assigned to territories or rights scopes that do not exist in or contradict the main agreement.
New schedule that is meant to supersede a prior one but not clearly marked as such, causing overlapping or conflicting catalog views.

what_to_look_for: Verify document completeness and page count: no missing pages, annexes, or referenced schedules.
Confirm all required sections are present for this deal type (parties, term, territory, rights, consideration, termination).
Check for proper execution and dating: signatures for all required parties and clear execution or effective dates.
Validate party information consistency across header, recitals, definitions, and signature blocks.
Review key commercial terms (rates, advances, recoupment, options) and ensure they are either explicit here or clearly delegated to schedules.
common_failure_modes: Missing pages, annexes, or schedules that are referenced in the main body of the agreement.
Inconsistent party names or entity descriptions between sections of the document.
Missing execution dates or obvious execution defects while the system treats the agreement as live.
Key commercial terms only described informally in email or side documents, not captured in the agreement or schedules.

what_to_look_for: Verify record completeness: required fields and key identifiers should be populated and non-placeholder.
Check for data consistency across related fields (e.g., dates, parties, deal type) and against linked records.
Validate required fields use expected formats: dates as dates, numbers as numbers, standardized enums where provided.
Look for formatting or encoding issues (garbled text, mojibake, unparsed symbols) that could break downstream systems.
Confirm field values match the underlying source documents or data extraction, not just assumptions.
common_failure_modes: Missing required field values that block automation or downstream reporting.
Inconsistent data formats across similar records (e.g., different date formats, mixed free-text and enums).
Encoding artifacts (mojibake) or OCR/extraction errors left uncorrected in key fields.
Misaligned data from source extraction (values shifted into the wrong columns or fields).
Using catch-all notes fields instead of dedicated structured fields for critical information.
